#Text=Brazilian tribe is neither a new discovery nor a hoax
#Text=Wednesday , June 25 , 2008
#Text=In late May to early June of 2008 , news broke that a previously undiscovered indigenous tribe had been found near the border between Brazil and Peru .
#Text=Worldwide media was quick to publish the story and the accompanying photographs taken by José Carlos Meirelles .
#Text=The photos showed people in full body paint aiming bows at the overhead aircraft from which the pictures were taken .
#Text=Wikinews covered the story as well .

#Text=In its Sunday edition , British newspaper The Observer had a story called " Secret of the ' lost ' tribe that was n't " which was about this " discovery " and revealed that the tribe had in fact been known to scientists , including Fundação Nacional do Índio ( FUNAI ) , the Brazilian protection agency for Indian interests .

column1: #Text=Some of the media got very carried away and started talking about undiscovered tribes — Fiona Watson
#Text=After this revelation , media newswires branded the original story a hoax .
#Text=These hoax claims spread nearly as quickly as the original story .
#Text=Rapidly , news sites even claimed that the photos were fake .
#Text=The true story , however , is more complicated than that .
#Text=The Observer ' s article featured an interview with José Carlos Meirelles , one of a handful so-called sertanistas that work for the FUNAI .
#Text=These are field agents that map the areas of uncontacted indigenous peoples , so that their habitat can be protected .
#Text=He admitted that his desire to protect these tribes had caused him to overstep his mission .
#Text=When given the use of an aircraft to seek out new tribes , Meirelles instead flew over an area where he knew a tribe had been observed decades ago .
#Text=Ultimately , he was hoping to prove that FUNAI 's policy of not contacting the tribes they observe is better for the tribes .
#Text=With this flight he hoped to find evidence that the tribe , discovered long ago , was better off for not being contacted .
#Text=" When I saw them painted red , I was satisfied , I was happy , " he said .
#Text=" Because painted red means they are ready for war , which to me says they are happy and healthy defending their territory . "
#Text=The photos are of a real tribe , long known to Meirelles and other scientists within FUNAI , but protected under Brazilian law .
#Text=Meirelles says he has no regrets , because he just wanted to prove these kind of tribes exist and deserve protection .
#Text=He said that Peruvian President Alan García had claimed that these tribes were imaginary and that he needed to prove they existed .
#Text=In doing so , he violated FUNAI policies by flying over their area and taking pictures .
#Text=Both are prohibited .
#Text=Meirelles claims he will protect the exact location of the tribe 's territory , even if tortured .
#Text=When I saw them painted red , I was satisfied , I was happy — José Carlos Meirelles
#Text=Former president of FUNAI , Sydney Possuelo , agreed that the publication of the photos was necessary to quell the doubt about the very existence such uncontacted indigenous peoples .

#Text=Survival International , a human rights organisation formed in 1969 that campaigns for the rights of indigenous tribal and uncontacted peoples , admits complicity in the distribution of the original story .
#Text=Survival International was instrumental in getting the original story international attention .
#Text=Nevertheless , Survival International said it did not mislead media because it never described the tribe as " lost " .
